Agents

Agent class

class Sandbox_V1_4.Agent(x: float, y: float, colour: str, theta: float = None, radius: float = 1, light: LightSource = None, energy_sensor_noisemaker=None, action_energy_cost: float = 0, metabolism_energy_cost: float = 0, alive: bool = True, maximum_energy: float = 0, initial_energy: float = 1, init_fun: Callable = None, perturb_fun: Callable = None, pheromone_manager=None, drop_interval=0.5, p_bump_noise=0)[source]

An Agent is an abstract subclass of System. Classes which represent specific types of mobile agents, e.g. Robot are subclasses of Agent.

An Agent is a mobile System with position and orientation. It is expected that an Agent will have sensors, a controller, and some way of moving through its environment.

When you subclass Agent, you will need to implement the following methods:

  • step_sensors(dt)

  • control(activations, dt)

  • step_actuators(speed_commands, dt)

  • integrate(actual_speeds, dt)

  • and update_children_positions()

  • as well as pygame_draw(self, screen, scale: float, shiftx: float, shifty: float), if you are going to animate your simulation

  • update_energy can also be optionally implemented, if you want your agent to have an internal energy level

These methods split up the Agent’s side of its sensorimotor loop. The main reason for splitting them up is to make it easier to subclass agent implementations. For example, to add sensors to an existing Agent subclass, you would only need to override step_sensors and control - step_actuators and integrate don’t need to be touched. Another example would be if you wanted to change the dynamics of motion when subclassing an existing Agent - it may only be necessary to override the integrate method, and leave the other methods as they are.

All instances of Agent will have two sensors: the first is an EnergySensor, which detects the agent’s internal energy level. The second is a BumpSensor, which can register collisions with other agents and objects.

__init__(self, x: float, y: float, colour: str, theta: float = None, radius: float = 1, light: LightSource = None, energy_sensor_noisemaker=None, action_energy_cost: float = 0, metabolism_energy_cost: float = 0, alive: bool = True, maximum_energy: float = 0, initial_energy: float = 1, init_fun: Callable = None, perturb_fun: Callable = None, pheromone_manager=None, drop_interval=0.5)[source]
Parameters:

  • x (float) – The Agent’s initial x-coordinate.

  • y (float) – The Agent’s initial y-coordinate.

  • theta (float) – The Agent’s initial orientation. Defaults to None.

  • radius (float) – The radius of the Agent’s body. Defaults to 1.

  • colour (str) – The colour of the Agent’s body.

  • light (LightSource) – The LightSource attached to the Agent’s body. Defaults to None.

  • energy_sensor_noisemaker (subclass of NoiseSource) – A source of noise for the Agent’s energy sensor. Defaults to None.

  • action_energy_cost (float) – The energetic cost of action. The actual cost for a subclass of Agent will differ from one class to another, and typically depend on how many motors the agent makes use of. Defaults to 0.

  • metabolism_energy_cost (float) – The energetic cost of existing. The main reason for this cost is that without it, agents can survive for indefinite periods without moving/acting at all. When agents can “die” by not acting, there is a pressure (e.g. selective pressure, if evolving) to act, and potentially to also adapt. Defaults to 0.

  • alive (bool) – If an agent runs our of energy, it will die, at which point its alive parameter will be set to False, and the agent will cease to act (although in the current implementation, its controller will continue to function as normal). Defaults to True.

  • maximum_energy (float) – The maximum energy level the agent can have. Defaults to 0.

  • initial_energy (float) – The agent’s initial energy level. Defaults to 1.

  • init_fun (function) – A function which can be used to set the initial state of the system in each simulation run. Defaults to None.

  • perturb_fun (function) – A function which can be used to perturb the system’s state. This will typically be used at the beginning of simulation runs. Defaults to None.

  • pheromone_manager (PheromoneManager) – If an Agent has a pheromone manager, then it will drop pheromones (similarly to an ant laying trails). Defaults to None.

  • drop_interval (float) – The rate at which the agent will drop pheromones, if its pheromone_manager is not None. Defaults to 0.5.

drop_pheromones(dt)[source]

All agents can potentially drop pheromones (see PheromoneSource), if they have pheromone managers (see PheromoneManager) passed to them when they are constructed. This method will make the agent drop pheromones all the time, at the constant rate specified by the agent’s drop_interval parameter.

Parameters:

dt (float) – The interval of time to integrate the pheromone drop timer over.

get_data()[source]

A function to get the data from an Agent, in the form of a string-keyed dict.

These data, as and when they are included in the returned dict, can be accessed with the following keys:

  • data inherited from System: see System

  • The history of the agent’s energy level over the simulation: data["energies"]

push(x: float = None, y: float = None, theta: float = None)[source]

A method used to “push” an Agent to a new position and orientation. The agent can be pushed in any single axis (x, y, rotation) or any combination of those axes.

This method is here for environmental interactions such as those between an Agent and an Arena. The Arena takes care of watching for collisions between agents and its walls, and when it detects one, it pushes the colliding agent back inside, using this method. It is important that this method is used, rather than just directly changing the agent’s x, y, and theta attributes, as this method will also update the states of attached systems, such as sensors.

Parameters:

  • x (float) – The x-coordinate to push the agent to. Defaults to None, in which case the agent’s x-coordinate will be unchanged.

  • y (float) – The y-coordinate to push the agent to. Defaults to None, in which case the agent’s y-coordinate will be unchanged.

  • theta (float) – The orientation to push the agent to. Defaults to None, in which case the agent’s orientation will be unchanged.

reset()[source]

Reset an Agent to its original state upon its construction, e.g. so that it can be re-used in another simulation run.

step(dt: float) → None[source]

Step the agent forwards in time.

Parameters:

dt (float) – Interval of time to integrate the agent’s dynamics over.

update_energy(actual_speeds, dt)[source]

A placeholder. Subclasses of Agent will need to implement this method, if they are to have internal energy levels.

param actual_speeds: the actual speeds of the agent’s motors. type actual_speeds: list[float]

Parameters:

dt (float) – The interval of time to integrate the energy cost over.

Robot class

class Sandbox_V1_4.Robot(x: float, y: float, controller: RobotController, sensors: List[LightSensor], sensor_angles: List[float], radius: float = 1, theta: float = 0, left_motor_max_speed: float = 2, right_motor_max_speed: float = 2, left_motor_inertia: float = 0, right_motor_inertia: float = 0, left_motor_noisemaker: NoiseSource = None, right_motor_noisemaker: NoiseSource = None, left_motor_reversed: bool = False, right_motor_reversed: bool = False, left_motor_sensor_noisemaker: NoiseSource = None, right_motor_sensor_noisemaker: NoiseSource = None, energy_sensor_noisemaker: NoiseSource = None, colour: str = 'darkblue', light: LightSource = None, action_energy_cost: float = 0, metabolism_energy_cost: float = 0, alive: bool = True, maximum_energy: float = 0, initial_energy: float = 1, consumables=None, init_fun: Callable = None, perturb_fun: Callable = None, pheromone_manager=None, drop_interval=0.5, p_bump_noise=0)[source]

A class to represent a robot with a differential drive.

__init__(self, x: float, y: float, controller: RobotController, sensors: List[LightSensor], sensor_angles: List[float], radius: float = 1, theta: float = 0, left_motor_max_speed: float = 2, right_motor_max_speed: float = 2, left_motor_inertia: float = 0, right_motor_inertia: float = 0, left_motor_noisemaker: NoiseSource = None, right_motor_noisemaker: NoiseSource = None, left_motor_reversed: bool = False, right_motor_reversed: bool = False, left_motor_sensor_noisemaker: NoiseSource = None, right_motor_sensor_noisemaker: NoiseSource = None, energy_sensor_noisemaker: NoiseSource = None, colour: str = 'darkblue', light: LightSource = None, action_energy_cost: float = 0, metabolism_energy_cost: float = 0, alive: bool = True, maximum_energy: float = 0, initial_energy: float = 1, consumables=None, init_fun: Callable = None, perturb_fun: Callable = None, pheromone_manager=None, drop_interval=0.5, p_bump_noise=0)[source]
Parameters:

  • x (float) – The Robot’s initial x-coordinate.

  • y (float) – The Robot’s initial y-coordinate.

  • theta (float) – The Robot’s initial orientation. Defaults to 0.

  • radius (float) – The radius of the Robot’s body. Defaults to 1.

  • light (LightSource) – The LightSource attached to the Robot’s body. Defaults to None.

  • colour (str) – The colour of the Robot’s body. Defaults to "darkblue".

  • energy_sensor_noisemaker (subclass of NoiseSource) – A source of noise for the Robot’s energy sensor. Defaults to None.

  • action_energy_cost (float) – The energetic cost of action. Defaults to 0. The cost of action in a single simulation step, for each of the robot’s 2 motors, is abs(motor speed) * dt * action_energy_cost.

  • metabolism_energy_cost (float) – The energetic cost of existing. The main reason for this cost is that without it, robots can survive for indefinite periods without moving/acting at all. When robots can “die” by not acting, there is a pressure (e.g. selective pressure, if evolving) to act, and potentially to also adapt. Defaults to 0.

  • alive (bool) – If a robot runs our of energy, it will “die”, at which point its alive parameter will be set to False, and the robot will cease to act (although in the current implementation, its controller will continue to function as normal). Defaults to True.

  • maximum_energy (float) – The maximum energy level the robot can have. Defaults to 0.

  • initial_energy (float) – The robot’s initial energy level. Defaults to 1.

  • init_fun (function) – A function which can be used to set the initial state of the system in each simulation run. Defaults to None.

  • perturb_fun (function) – A function which can be used to perturb the robot’s state. This will typically be used at the beginning of simulation runs. Defaults to None.

  • pheromone_manager (PheromoneManager) – If a Robot has a pheromone manager, then it will drop pheromones (similarly to an ant laying trails). Defaults to None.

  • drop_interval (float) – The interval between which the robot will drop pheromones, if its pheromone_manager is not None. Defaults to 0.5.

  • left_motor_max_speed (float) – The maximum speed, in either direction, for the robot’s left motor. Defaults to 2.

  • right_motor_max_speed (float) – The maximum speed, in either direction, for the robot’s right motor. Defaults to 2.

  • left_motor_inertia (float) – The inertia (resistance to change of speed) of the robot’s left motor. Defaults to 0.

  • right_motor_inertia (float) – The inertia (resistance to change of speed) of the robot’s right motor. Defaults to 0.

  • left_motor_noisemaker (NoiseSource) – A source of noise for the robot’s left Motor.

  • right_motor_noisemaker (NoiseSource) – A source of noise for the robot’s right Motor.

  • left_motor_reversed (bool) – A flag to determine whether the robot’s left motor is running in the forwards (for False) or reversed direction (for True). Defaults to False.

  • right_motor_reversed (bool) – A flag to determine whether the robot’s right motor is running in the forwards (for False) or reversed direction (for True). Defaults to False.

  • left_motor_sensor_noisemaker (NoiseSource) – A source of noise for the robot’s left MotorSpeedSensor.

  • right_motor_sensor_noisemaker (NoiseSource) – A source of noise for the robot’s right MotorSpeedSensor.

  • controller (RobotController) – The robot’s controller.

  • sensors (list[Sensor]) – A Robot has a list of 4 sensors by default: an internal energy sensor, a bump sensor, and a motor speed sensor for each of its 2 motors. The list of sensors passed in here will be joined to that list. The robot’s energy sensor is at index 0 in the list, the bump sensor is at index 1, its left motor speed sensor is at index 2, and its right motor speed sensor is at index 3. Therefore, any other sensors will be at indices 4 and up.

  • sensor_angles (list[float]) – A list of angles for the sensors passed in as the sensors parameter. This list should have exactly the same length as sensors. For any sensor which has None as its corresponding entry in sensor_angles, its position will be at the centre of the robot’s body. For any sensor which has an angle specified, the sensor will lie on the circumference of the robot’s body, at the specified angle from its forward direction.

  • consumables (list(Consumable)) – The list of consumables which this agent can consume.

control(activations: List[float], dt: float) → List[float][source]

Only called from step().

A method which gets motor speed commands by calling the step method of the robot’s controller.

Parameters:

  • dt (float) – Interval of time to integrate the robot’s controller over.

  • activations (list[float]) – The sensory inputs to the robot’s controller. A list of the activation levels for each of the robot’s sensors.

draw(ax) → None[source]

Draw robot in specified Matplotlib axes.

Parameters:

ax (Matplotlib axes) – The Matplotlib axes to draw the robot on.

get_data() → Dict[str, Dict[str, Any]][source]

A function to get the data from an Robot, in the form of a string-keyed dict.

These data, as and when they are included in the returned dict, can be accessed with the following keys:

  • data inherited from Agent: see Agent

  • class name (Robot): data["classname"]

  • data from the robot’s controller: data["controller"]

  • data from the robot’s sensors: data["sensors"]

  • data from the robot’s motors: data["motors"]

integrate(speeds: List[float], dt: float) → None[source]

Integrate the robot’s motion based on its motor speeds.

Only called from step().

Applies a motor activation vector to a robot state, and simulates the consequences using Euler integration over a dt interval.

Parameters:

  • dt (float) – Interval of time to integrate the robot’s motion over.

  • speeds (list[float]) – The robot’s motor speeds.

pygame_draw(screen, scale: float, shiftx: float, shifty: float) → None[source]

Draw robot on PyGame display.

Parameters:

  • screen (PyGame display) – The PyGame display to draw on.

  • scale (float) – The scale to draw at.

  • shiftx (float) – The offset from centre in the x-axis for drawing.

  • shifty (float) – The offset from centre in the y-axis for drawing.

reset(reset_controller: bool = True) → None[source]

This method resets a robot’s state and simulation data to their initial values, so that it can be used again.

Parameters:

reset_controller (bool) – determines whether or not the robot’s controller is also reset, defaults to True. This is because sometimes you might want to reset a robot and simulate it again taking advantage of any information or learning which the controller has acquired.

step_actuators(speed_commands: List[float], dt: float) → List[float][source]

Update the robot’s motor speeds, based on the commands from the robot’s controller and its motors’ dynamics (i.e. current speeds and inertias).

Parameters:

  • dt (float) – Interval of time to integrate the robot’s motors over.

  • speed_commands (list[float]) – The motor speed commands which are generated by the robot’s controller.

step_sensors(dt: float) → List[float][source]

Only called from step().

A method which steps the sensors in the robot’s sensors list, and returns the sensor activations in a list.

Parameters:

dt (float) – Interval of time to integrate the robot’s sensors over.

update_children_positions() → None[source]

This method is used to update the positions and orientations of a robot’s attached subsystems, such as its sensors, as the robot moves.

update_energy(actual_speeds, dt)[source]

Update the robot’s energy level, based on its metabolic and action costs.

Parameters:

  • dt (float) – Interval of time to integrate the robot’s energy losses over.

  • actual_speeds (list[float]) – The robot’s current motor speeds.

Ant class

class Sandbox_V1_4.Ant(x: float, y: float, theta: float, controller: AntController, sensors: List[Sensor], sensor_angles: List[float], radius: float = 1, move_motor_max_speed: float = 2, move_motor_inertia: float = 0, move_motor_reversed: bool = False, move_motor_noisemaker: NoiseSource = None, move_motor_sensor_noisemaker: NoiseSource = None, turn_motor_max_speed: float = 0.4, turn_motor_inertia: float = 0, turn_motor_reversed: bool = False, turn_motor_noisemaker: NoiseSource = None, turn_motor_sensor_noisemaker: NoiseSource = None, colour: str = '0x6F0E00FF', light: LightSource = None, energy_sensor_noisemaker: NoiseSource = None, compass_sensor_noisemaker: NoiseSource = None, action_energy_cost: float = 0, metabolism_energy_cost: float = 0, alive: bool = True, maximum_energy: float = 0, initial_energy: float = 1, consumables=None, init_fun: Callable = None, perturb_fun: Callable = None, pheromone_manager=None, drop_interval=0.5, p_bump_noise=0)[source]
__init__(x: float, y: float, theta: float, controller: AntController, sensors: List[Sensor], sensor_angles: List[float], radius: float = 1, move_motor_max_speed: float = 2, move_motor_inertia: float = 0, move_motor_reversed: bool = False, move_motor_noisemaker: NoiseSource = None, move_motor_sensor_noisemaker: NoiseSource = None, turn_motor_max_speed: float = 0.4, turn_motor_inertia: float = 0, turn_motor_reversed: bool = False, turn_motor_noisemaker: NoiseSource = None, turn_motor_sensor_noisemaker: NoiseSource = None, colour: str = '0x6F0E00FF', light: LightSource = None, energy_sensor_noisemaker: NoiseSource = None, compass_sensor_noisemaker: NoiseSource = None, action_energy_cost: float = 0, metabolism_energy_cost: float = 0, alive: bool = True, maximum_energy: float = 0, initial_energy: float = 1, consumables=None, init_fun: Callable = None, perturb_fun: Callable = None, pheromone_manager=None, drop_interval=0.5, p_bump_noise=0)[source]
Parameters:

  • x (float) – The Ant’s initial x-coordinate.

  • y (float) – The Ant’s initial y-coordinate.

  • theta (float) – The Ant’s initial orientation.

  • controller (AntController) – The ant’s controller.

  • sensors (list[Sensor]) – An Ant has a list of 5 sensors by default: an internal energy sensor, a compass sensors, and a motor speed sensor for each of its 2 motors. The list of sensors passed in here will be joined to that list. The ant’s EnergySensor is at index 0 in the list, its BumpSensor is at index 1, its CompassSensor is at index 2, and its move and turn motor sensors are at indices 3 and 4 respectively. Therefore, any other sensors will be at indices 5 and up.

  • sensor_angles (list[float]) – A list of angles for the sensors passed in as the sensors parameter. This list should have exactly the same length as sensors. For any sensor which has None as its corresponding entry in sensor_angles, its position will be at the centre of the ant’s body. For any sensor which has an angle specified, the sensor will lie on the circumference of the ant’s body, at the specified angle from its forward direction.

  • radius (float) – The radius of the Ant’s body. Defaults to 1.

  • move_motor_max_speed (float) – The maximum speed that the ant can move at in the x-y plane. Defaults to 2

  • move_motor_inertia (float) – The inertia on the ant’s move motor. Defaults to 0.

  • move_motor_reversed (bool) – The reversed state of the ant’s move motor. Defaults to False.

  • move_motor_noisemaker (NoiseSource) – The noise source for the ant’s move motor. Defaults to None.

  • move_motor_sensor_noisemaker – The noise source for the ant’s move motor sensor. Defaults to None.

  • turn_motor_max_speed (float) – The maximum speed for the ant’s turn motor. Defaults to 0.4

  • turn_motor_inertia (float) – The inertia on the ant’s turn motor. Defaults to 0.

  • turn_motor_reversed (bool) – The reversed state of the ant’s turn motor. Defaults to False.

  • turn_motor_noisemaker (NoiseSource) – The noise source for the ant’s turn motor. Defaults to None.

  • turn_motor_sensor_noisemaker (NoiseSource) – The noise source for the ant’s turn motor sensor. Defaults to None.

  • colour (str) – The colour of the ant’s body. Defaults to '0x6F0E00FF

  • light (LightSource) – The LightSource attached to the Ant’s body. Defaults to None.

  • energy_sensor_noisemaker (subclass of NoiseSource) – A source of noise for the Ant’s energy sensor. Defaults to None.

  • compass_sensor_noisemaker (NoiseSource) – The noise source for the ant’s compass sensor. Defaults to None,

  • action_energy_cost (float) – The energetic cost of action. Defaults to 0. The cost of action in a single simulation step, for each of the ant’s 2 motors, is abs(motor speed) * dt * action_energy_cost.

  • metabolism_energy_cost (float) – The energetic cost of existing. The main reason for this cost is that without it, ants can survive for indefinite periods without moving/acting at all. When ants can “die” by not acting, there is a pressure (e.g. selective pressure, if evolving) to act, and potentially to also adapt. Defaults to 0.

  • alive (bool) – If an ant runs our of energy, it will “die”, at which point its alive parameter will be set to False, and the ant will cease to act (although in the current implementation, its controller will continue to function as normal). Defaults to True.

  • maximum_energy (float) – The maximum energy level the ant can have. Defaults to 0.

  • initial_energy (float) – The ant’s initial energy level. Defaults to 1.

  • init_fun (function) – A function which can be used to set the initial state of the system in each simulation run. Defaults to None.

  • perturb_fun (function) – A function which can be used to perturb the ant’s state. This will typically be used at the beginning of simulation runs. Defaults to None.

  • pheromone_manager (PheromoneManager) – If a Ant has a pheromone manager, then it will drop pheromones (similarly to an ant laying trails). Defaults to None.

  • drop_interval (float) – The interval between which the ant will drop pheromones, if its pheromone_manager is not None. Defaults to 0.5.

  • consumables (list(Consumable)) – The list of consumables which this agent can consume.

  • data inherited from Agent: see Agent

  • class name (Ant): data["classname"]

  • data from the ant’s controller: data["controller"]

  • data from the ant’s sensors: data["sensors"]

step_actuators(speed_commands: List[float], dt: float) → List[float][source]

Parameters:

  • speed_commands (list[float]) – The motor speed commands which are generated by the ant’s controller.

step_sensors(dt: float) → List[float][source]

Only called from step().

A method which steps the sensors in the ant’s sensors list, and returns the sensor activations in a list.

Parameters:

dt (float) – Interval of time to integrate the ant’s sensors over.

update_children_positions() → None[source]

This method is used to update the positions and orientations of a ant’s attached subsystems, such as its sensors, as the ant moves.

update_energy(actual_speeds, dt)[source]

Update the ant’s energy level, based on its metabolic and action costs.

Parameters:

  • dt (float) – Interval of time to integrate the ant’s energy losses over.

  • actual_speeds (list[float]) – The ant’s current motor speeds.

Bee class

class Sandbox_V1_4.Bee(x: float, y: float, theta: float, heading: float, controller: BeeController, sensors: List[Sensor], sensor_angles: List[float], radius: float = 1, max_speed: float = 2, theta_inertia: float = 0, speed_inertia: float = 0, heading_inertia: float = 0, colour: str = '0x00FFFFFF', light=None, speed_motor_noisemaker=None, heading_motor_noisemaker=None, theta_motor_noisemaker=None, speed_motor_sensor_noisemaker=None, heading_motor_sensor_noisemaker=None, theta_motor_sensor_noisemaker=None, energy_sensor_noisemaker: NoiseSource = None, compass_sensor_noisemaker: NoiseSource = None, heading_sensor_noisemaker: NoiseSource = None, action_energy_cost: float = 0, metabolism_energy_cost: float = 0, alive: bool = True, maximum_energy: float = 0, initial_energy: float = 1, consumables=None, init_fun: Callable = None, perturb_fun: Callable = None, pheromone_manager=None, drop_interval=0.5, p_bump_noise=0)[source]

A class to represent a bee, or a drone like a quadcopter, which can control its orientation and direction of travel independently.

__init__(self, x: float, y: float, theta: float, heading: float, controller: BeeController, sensors: List[Sensor], sensor_angles: List[float], radius: float = 1, max_speed: float = 2, theta_inertia: float = 0, speed_inertia: float = 0, heading_inertia: float = 0, colour: str = '0x00FFFFFF', light=None, speed_motor_noisemaker=None, heading_motor_noisemaker=None, theta_motor_noisemaker=None, speed_motor_sensor_noisemaker=None, heading_motor_sensor_noisemaker=None, theta_motor_sensor_noisemaker=None, energy_sensor_noisemaker: NoiseSource = None, compass_sensor_noisemaker: NoiseSource = None, heading_sensor_noisemaker: NoiseSource = None, action_energy_cost: float = 0, metabolism_energy_cost: float = 0, alive: bool = True, maximum_energy: float = 0, initial_energy: float = 1, consumables=None, init_fun: Callable = None, perturb_fun: Callable = None, pheromone_manager=None, drop_interval=0.5, p_bump_noise=0)[source]
Parameters:

  • x (float) – The Bee’s initial x-coordinate.

  • y (float) – The Bee’s initial y-coordinate.

  • theta (float) – The Bee’s initial orientation. Defaults to 0.

  • radius (float) – The radius of the Bee’s body. Defaults to 1.

  • light (LightSource) – The LightSource attached to the Bee’s body. Defaults to None.

  • heading (float) – The direction the bee will fly in.

  • controller (BeeController) – the bee’s controller.

  • sensors (list[Sensor]) – A Bee has a list of 7 sensors by default: an internal energy sensor, a bump sensor, compass and heading sensors, and a motor speed sensor for each of its 3 motors. The list of sensors passed in here will be joined to that list. The bee’s EnergySensor is at index 0 in the list, its BumpSensor is at index 1 in this list, its CompassSensor is at index 2, and its HeadingSensor is at index 3. Its MotorSpeedSensor for its translational speed is at index 4, its MotorSpeedSensor for its angular speed (to change its body orientation) is at index 5, and its MotorSpeedSensor for its angular heading speed (to change its direction of travel) is at index 6. Therefore, any other sensors will be at indices 7 and up.

  • sensor_angles (list[float]) – A list of angles for the sensors passed in as the sensors parameter. This list should have exactly the same length as sensors. For any sensor which has None as its corresponding entry in sensor_angles, its position will be at the centre of the bee’s body. For any sensor which has an angle specified, the sensor will lie on the circumference of the bee’s body, at the specified angle from its forward direction.

  • max_speed (float) – The maximum speed that the bee can move at in the x-y plane. Defaults to 2.

  • theta_inertia (float) – The inertia on the bee’s orientation turning motor. Defaults to 0.

  • speed_inertia (float) – The inertia on the bee’s linear speed motor. Defaults to 0.

  • heading_inertia (float) – The inertia on the bee’s heading turning motor. Defaults to 0.

  • speed_motor_noisemaker (NoiseSource) – The noise source for the bee’s translational (x-y plane) speed motor. Defaults to None,

  • heading_motor_noisemaker (NoiseSource) – The noise source for the bee’s heading (direction of travel) speed motor. Defaults to None,

  • theta_motor_noisemaker (NoiseSource) – The noise source for the bee’s orientation (theta) speed motor. Defaults to None,

  • heading_motor_sensor_noisemaker (NoiseSource) – The noise source for the bee’s heading speed motor sensor. Defaults to None,

  • theta_motor_sensor_noisemaker (NoiseSource) – The noise source for the bee’s orientation speed motor sensor. Defaults to None,

  • compass_sensor_noisemaker (NoiseSource) – The noise source for the bee’s compass sensor. Defaults to None,

  • heading_sensor_noisemaker (NoiseSource) – The noise source for the bee’s heading speed motor. Defaults to None,

  • colour (str) – The colour of the Bee’s body. Defaults to '0x00FFFFFF'.

  • energy_sensor_noisemaker (subclass of NoiseSource) – A source of noise for the Bee’s energy sensor. Defaults to None.

  • action_energy_cost (float) – The energetic cost of action. Defaults to 0. The cost of action in a single simulation step, for each of the bee’s 2 motors, is abs(motor speed) * dt * action_energy_cost.

  • metabolism_energy_cost (float) – The energetic cost of existing. The main reason for this cost is that without it, bees can survive for indefinite periods without moving/acting at all. When bees can “die” by not acting, there is a pressure (e.g. selective pressure, if evolving) to act, and potentially to also adapt. Defaults to 0.

  • alive (bool) – If a bee runs our of energy, it will “die”, at which point its alive parameter will be set to False, and the bee will cease to act (although in the current implementation, its controller will continue to function as normal). Defaults to True.

  • maximum_energy (float) – The maximum energy level the bee can have. Defaults to 0.

  • initial_energy (float) – The bee’s initial energy level. Defaults to 1.

  • init_fun (function) – A function which can be used to set the initial state of the system in each simulation run. Defaults to None.

  • perturb_fun (function) – A function which can be used to perturb the bee’s state. This will typically be used at the beginning of simulation runs. Defaults to None.

  • pheromone_manager (PheromoneManager) – If a Bee has a pheromone manager, then it will drop pheromones (similarly to an ant laying trails). Defaults to None.

  • drop_interval (float) – The interval between which the bee will drop pheromones, if its pheromone_manager is not None. Defaults to 0.5.

  • consumables (list(Consumable)) – The list of consumables which this agent can consume.

control(activations: List[float], dt: float) → List[float][source]

Only called from step().

A method which gets motor speed commands by calling the step method of the bee’s controller.

Parameters:

  • dt (float) – Interval of time to integrate the bee’s controller over.

  • activations (list[float]) – The sensory inputs to the bee’s controller. A list of the activation levels for each of the bee’s sensors.

draw(ax) → None[source]

Draw bee in specified Matplotlib axes.

Parameters:

ax (Matplotlib axes) – The Matplotlib axes to draw the bee on.

get_data() → Dict[str, Dict[str, Any]][source]

A function to get the data from a Bee, in the form of a string-keyed dict.

These data, as and when they are included in the returned dict, can be accessed with the following keys:

  • data inherited from Agent: see Agent

  • class name (Bee): data["classname"]

  • data from the bee’s controller: data["controller"]

  • data from the bee’s sensors: data["sensors"]

  • data from the bee’s motors: data["motors"]

  • a complete history of the bee’s speed: data["speeds"]

  • a complete history of the bee’s heading: data["headings"]

integrate(speeds: List[float], dt: float) → None[source]

Integrate the bee’s motion based on its motor speeds.

Only called from step().

Applies a motor activation vector to a bee state, and simulates the consequences using Euler integration over a dt interval.

Parameters:

  • dt (float) – Interval of time to integrate the bee’s motion over.

  • speeds (list[float]) – The bee’s motor speeds.

  • scale (float) – The scale to draw at.

  • shiftx (float) – The offset from centre in the x-axis for drawing.

  • shifty (float) – The offset from centre in the y-axis for drawing.

reset(reset_controller: bool = True) → None[source]

This method resets a bee’s state and simulation data to their initial values, so that it can be used again.

Parameters:

reset_controller (bool) – determines whether or not the bee’s controller is also reset, defaults to True. This is because sometimes you might want to reset a bee and simulate it again taking advantage of any information or learning which the controller has acquired.

step_actuators(speed_commands: List[float], dt: float) → List[float][source]

Update the bee’s motor speeds, based on the commands from the bee’s controller and its motors’ dynamics (i.e. current speeds and inertias).

Parameters:

  • dt (float) – Interval of time to integrate the bee’s motors over.

  • speed_commands (list[float]) – The motor speed commands which are generated by the bee’s controller.

Parameters:

FauxKilobot class

class Sandbox_V1_4.FauxKilobot(x: float, y: float, theta: float, controller: FauxKilobotController, sensors: List[Sensor], sensor_angles: List[float], radius: float = 1, move_motor_max_speed: float = 2, colour: str = '#A020F0', light: LightSource = None, energy_sensor_noisemaker: NoiseSource = None, action_energy_cost: float = 0, metabolism_energy_cost: float = 0, alive: bool = True, maximum_energy: float = 0, initial_energy: float = 1, consumables=None, init_fun: Callable = None, perturb_fun: Callable = None, pheromone_manager=None, drop_interval=0.5, radio_t_range=3, radio_r_range=3, radio_enabled=True, move_motor_sensor_noisemaker=None, turn_motor_sensor_noisemaker=None, move_motor_noisemaker=None, turn_motor_noisemaker=None, p_bump_noise=0)[source]

A class to simulate a robot which is loosely inspired by Kilobot.

__init__(x: float, y: float, theta: float, controller: FauxKilobotController, sensors: List[Sensor], sensor_angles: List[float], radius: float = 1, move_motor_max_speed: float = 2, colour: str = '#A020F0', light: LightSource = None, energy_sensor_noisemaker: NoiseSource = None, action_energy_cost: float = 0, metabolism_energy_cost: float = 0, alive: bool = True, maximum_energy: float = 0, initial_energy: float = 1, consumables=None, init_fun: Callable = None, perturb_fun: Callable = None, pheromone_manager=None, drop_interval=0.5, radio_t_range=3, radio_r_range=3, radio_enabled=True, move_motor_sensor_noisemaker=None, turn_motor_sensor_noisemaker=None, move_motor_noisemaker=None, turn_motor_noisemaker=None, p_bump_noise=0)[source]

__init__(self, x: float, y: float, theta: float, controller: FauxKilobotController, sensors: List[Sensor], sensor_angles: List[float], radius: float=1, move_motor_max_speed: float=2, colour: str=’#A020F0’, light: LightSource=None, energy_sensor_noisemaker: NoiseSource=None, action_energy_cost: float=0, metabolism_energy_cost: float=0, alive: bool=True, maximum_energy: float=0, initial_energy: float=1, consumables=None, init_fun: Callable=None, perturb_fun: Callable=None, pheromone_manager=None, drop_interval=0.5, radio_t_range=3, radio_r_range=3, radio_enabled=True, move_motor_sensor_noisemaker=None, turn_motor_sensor_noisemaker=None, move_motor_noisemaker=None, turn_motor_noisemaker=None, p_bump_noise=0)

Parameters:

  • x (float) – The FauxKilobot’s initial x-coordinate.

  • y (float) – The FauxKilobot’s initial y-coordinate.

  • theta (float) – The FauxKilobot’s initial orientation. Defaults to 0.

  • radius (float) – The radius of the FauxKilobot’s body. Defaults to 1.

  • colour (str) – The colour of the FauxKilobot’s body. Defaults to '#A020F0'.

  • light (LightSource) – The LightSource attached to the FauxKilobot’s body. Defaults to None.

  • controller (FauxKilobotController) – the FauxKilobot’s controller.

  • sensors (list[Sensor]) – A FauxKilobot has a list of 6 sensors by default: an internal energy sensor, a bump sensor, compass and heading sensors, and a motor speed sensor for each of its 2 motors. The list of sensors passed in here will be joined to that list. The FauxKilobot’s EnergySensor is at index 0 in the list, its BumpSensor is at index 1 in the list, its CompassSensor is at index 2, and its HeadingSensor is at index 3. Its MotorSpeedSensor for its translational speed is at index 4, and its MotorSpeedSensor for its angular speed (to change its body orientation) is at index 5. Therefore, any other sensors will be at indices 6 and up.

  • sensor_angles (list[float]) – A list of angles for the sensors passed in as the sensors parameter. This list should have exactly the same length as sensors. For any sensor which has None as its corresponding entry in sensor_angles, its position will be at the centre of the FauxKilobot’s body. For any sensor which has an angle specified, the sensor will lie on the circumference of the FauxKilobot’s body, at the specified angle from its forward direction.

  • energy_sensor_noisemaker (subclass of NoiseSource) – A source of noise for the FauxKilobot’s energy sensor. Defaults to None.

  • action_energy_cost (float) – The energetic cost of action. Defaults to 0. The cost of action in a single simulation step, for each of the FauxKilobot’s 2 motors, is abs(motor speed) * dt * action_energy_cost.

  • metabolism_energy_cost (float) – The energetic cost of existing. The main reason for this cost is that without it, FauxKilobots can survive for indefinite periods without moving/acting at all. When FauxKilobots can “die” by not acting, there is a pressure (e.g. selective pressure, if evolving) to act, and potentially to also adapt. Defaults to 0.

  • alive (bool) – If a FauxKilobot runs our of energy, it will “die”, at which point its alive parameter will be set to False, and the FauxKilobot will cease to act (although in the current implementation, its controller will continue to function as normal). Defaults to True.

  • maximum_energy (float) – The maximum energy level the FauxKilobot can have. Defaults to 0.

  • initial_energy (float) – The FauxKilobot’s initial energy level. Defaults to 1.

  • init_fun (function) – A function which can be used to set the initial state of the system in each simulation run. Defaults to None.

  • perturb_fun (function) – A function which can be used to perturb the FauxKilobot’s state. This will typically be used at the beginning of simulation runs. Defaults to None.

  • pheromone_manager (PheromoneManager) – If a FauxKilobot has a pheromone manager, then it will drop pheromones (similarly to an FauxKilobot laying trails). Defaults to None.

  • drop_interval (float) – The interval between which the FauxKilobot will drop pheromones, if its pheromone_manager is not None. Defaults to 0.5.

  • consumables (list(Consumable)) – The list of consumables which this agent can consume.

  • turn_motor_noisemaker (NoiseSource) – The noise source for the FauxKilobot’s turn motor. Defaults to None.

  • turn_motor_sensor_noisemaker (NoiseSource) – The noise source for the FauxKilobot’s turn motor sensor. Defaults to None.

  • move_motor_noisemaker (NoiseSource) – The noise source for the FauxKilobot’s move motor. Defaults to None.

  • move_motor_sensor_noisemaker – The noise source for the FauxKilobot’s move motor sensor. Defaults to None.

  • move_motor_max_speed (float) – The maximum speed that the FauxKilobot can move at in the x-y plane. Defaults to 2

  • radio_t_range (float) – FauxKilobot’s Radio transmitter range. Defaults to 3.

  • radio_r_range (float) – FauxKilobot’s Radio receiver range. Defaults to 3.

  • radio_enabled (bool) – A flag to set whether the FauxKilobot’s Radio is enabled. Defaults to True.

Only called from step().

Parameters:

  • dt (float) – Interval of time to integrate the FauxKilobot’s controller over.

  • activations (list[float]) – The sensory inputs to the FauxKilobot’s controller. A list of the activation levels for each of the FauxKilobot’s sensors.

get_data() → Dict[str, Dict[str, Any]][source]

A function to get the data from a FauxKilobot, in the form of a string-keyed dict.

These data, as and when they are included in the returned dict, can be accessed with the following keys:

  • data inherited from Agent: see Agent

  • class name (FauxKilobot): data["classname"]

  • data from the FauxKilobot’s controller: data["controller"]

  • data from the FauxKilobot’s sensors: data["sensors"]

  • data from the FauxKilobot’s motors: data["motors"]

  • a complete history of the FauxKilobot’s heading: data["headings"]

Robot builders

Sandbox_V1_4.factories.robot_builder.new_light_seeking_Robot(x: float, y: float, theta: float, light_sources: List[LightSource], gain: float = 1, controller: RobotController = None, left_sensor_noisemaker: NoiseSource = None, right_sensor_noisemaker: NoiseSource = None, left_motor_noisemaker: NoiseSource = None, right_motor_noisemaker: NoiseSource = None, left_motor_max_speed=4, right_motor_max_speed=4, label=None, FOV=2.356194490192345, left_sensor_angle=0.7853981633974483, right_sensor_angle=-0.7853981633974483, left_motor_inertia: float = 0, right_motor_inertia: float = 0, init_fun: Callable = None, perturb_fun: Callable = None, pheromone_manager=None, drop_interval=2, left_sensor_colour: str = 'red', right_sensor_colour: str = 'red') → Robot[source]

A convenience function for preparing a light-seeking robot (actually, its controller doesn’t have to be light-seeking - it is only the morphology which will match Braitenberg’s simpler vehicles)
